name: 'Re' Words Quiz | Words Within Words | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which of these words is synonymous with 'reborn'?
questions.explanation:
Renascent.

	The word 'Renaissance' also has s similar word origin, literally meaning 'rebirth'!  The term 'renascent' is derived from the French, but originally of Latin origin.

questions.text: One of these words can mean either 'rare' or 'pretentious', but which?
questions.explanation:
Recherche.

	From the old French "rechercher", to research.  The word can also mean 'exquisite' and 'overrefined'.  Quite a useful word indeed then!

questions.text: A person who is a 'non-conformist' may have which of these terms most aptly applied to them?
questions.explanation:
Recusant.

	This term first came into use during the 16th century in England and was used to describe those individuals who 'rebelled' against the monarchy and refused to switch to the Church of England.  They rather remained Roman Catholics, regardless of the penalties.

questions.text: Let's do something spooky now.  Which of these frightful terms is synonymous with 'ghost'?
questions.explanation:
Revenant.

	More specifically, a person who has returned from the land of the dead, it is derived from the French "revenir", which means 'return'.  How terrifying!

questions.text: If a flower has the quality of blooming more than once a year, which of these words might be used to describe it?
questions.explanation:
Remontant.

	Yet another French term, what a surprise!  It's true, the French do have many words that begin with 're-', as do we in English.

questions.text: If one is said to be 'cunning' like a fox, which of these terms would best be used to describe him or her?
questions.explanation:
Renard.

	The term 'renard' is actually archaic, from Middle English.  It is identical to the term 'reynard', which of course is from the French...for fox.

questions.text: Which of the following is a noun used for someone who seems addicted to publicity?
questions.explanation:
Reclame.

	The word 'reclame' is, of course, derived from the French...we owe the French something fierce!  The French word 'réclamer' means simply 'to claim'!  I do think Michael Jackson's réclame is excessive, don't you?

questions.text: This 're' term is equivalent to an 'activity involving eating'.  Which of the following words fits this description?
questions.explanation:
Repast.

	Have you had your morning 'repast'?  If not, please finish this quiz slowly and carefully and then go on with your dining...bon appetite!

questions.text: Which of these terms could be used to describe someone or something that is 'fearsome'?
questions.explanation:
Redoubtable.

	Another term from the French, an extraordinarily rich language!  'Redoubtable' is another way to say 'formidable', we must always expand our vocabulary...there's nothing wrong with having several ways to express ourselves, even if the task is redoubtable!

questions.text: Which of these terms would be helpful in describing a 'renewal of' a disease, or some other misfortune?
questions.explanation:
Recrudescence.

	From the Latin, this time, 'recrudescere' which means 'to grow raw again'.  Well...I hope you have enjoyed this quiz, and that your interest in 're' words has been revived, rekindled and reenforced...and that your newly found vocabulary will reverberate resoundingly from henceforth!
